location: Elsinore. A room in the castle.

lines.text: Enter QUEEN GERTRUDE, HORATIO, and a Gentleman

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: I will not speak with her.

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: She is importunate, indeed distract: Her mood will needs be pitied.

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: What would she have?

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: She speaks much of her father; says she hears There's tricks i' the world; and hems, and beats her heart; Spurns enviously at straws; speaks things in doubt, That carry but half sense: her speech is nothing, Yet the unshaped use of it doth move The hearers to collection; they aim at it, And botch the words up fit to their own thoughts; Which, as her winks, and nods, and gestures yield them, Indeed would make one think there might be thought, Though nothing sure, yet much unhappily.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: 'Twere good she were spoken with; for she may strew Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds.

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Let her come in. To my sick soul, as sin's true nature is, Each toy seems prologue to some great amiss: So full of artless jealousy is guilt, It spills itself in fearing to be spilt.
Exit HORATIO
Re-enter HORATIO, with OPHELIA

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Where is the beauteous majesty of Denmark?

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: How now, Ophelia!

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: [Sings] How should I your true love know From another one? By his cockle hat and staff, And his sandal shoon.

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Alas, sweet lady, what imports this song?

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Say you? nay, pray you, mark. He is dead and gone, lady, He is dead and gone; At his head a grass-green turf, At his heels a stone.
Sings

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Nay, but, Ophelia,--

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Pray you, mark. White his shroud as the mountain snow,--
Sings
Enter KING CLAUDIUS

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Alas, look here, my lord.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: [Sings] Larded with sweet flowers Which bewept to the grave did go With true-love showers.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: How do you, pretty lady?

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Well, God 'ild you! They say the owl was a baker's daughter. Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be. God be at your table!

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Conceit upon her father.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Pray you, let's have no words of this; but when they ask you what it means, say you this: To-morrow is Saint Valentine's day, All in the morning betime, And I a maid at your window, To be your Valentine. Then up he rose, and donn'd his clothes, And dupp'd the chamber-door; Let in the maid, that out a maid Never departed more.
Sings

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Pretty Ophelia!

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: Indeed, la, without an oath, I'll make an end on't: By Gis and by Saint Charity, Alack, and fie for shame! Young men will do't, if they come to't; By cock, they are to blame. Quoth she, before you tumbled me, You promised me to wed. So would I ha' done, by yonder sun, An thou hadst not come to my bed.
Sings

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: How long hath she been thus?

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: I hope all will be well. We must be patient: but I cannot choose but weep, to think they should lay him i' the cold ground. My brother shall know of it: and so I thank you for your good counsel. Come, my coach! Good night, ladies; good night, sweet ladies; good night, good night.
Exit

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Follow her close; give her good watch, I pray you. O, this is the poison of deep grief; it springs All from her father's death. O Gertrude, Gertrude, When sorrows come, they come not single spies But in battalions. First, her father slain: Next, your son gone; and he most violent author Of his own just remove: the people muddied, Thick and unwholesome in their thoughts and whispers, For good Polonius' death; and we have done but greenly, In hugger-mugger to inter him: poor Ophelia Divided from herself and her fair judgment, Without the which we are pictures, or mere beasts: Last, and as much containing as all these, Her brother is in secret come from France; Feeds on his wonder, keeps himself in clouds, And wants not buzzers to infect his ear With pestilent speeches of his father's death; Wherein necessity, of matter beggar'd, Will nothing stick our person to arraign In ear and ear. O my dear Gertrude, this, Like to a murdering-piece, in many places Gives me superfluous death.
Exit HORATIO
A noise within

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Alack, what noise is this?

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Where are my Switzers? Let them guard the door. What is the matter?
Enter another Gentleman

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Save yourself, my lord: The ocean, overpeering of his list, Eats not the flats with more impetuous haste Than young Laertes, in a riotous head, O'erbears your officers. The rabble call him lord; And, as the world were now but to begin, Antiquity forgot, custom not known, The ratifiers and props of every word, They cry 'Choose we: Laertes shall be king:' Caps, hands, and tongues, applaud it to the clouds: 'Laertes shall be king, Laertes king!'

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: How cheerfully on the false trail they cry! O, this is counter, you false Danish dogs!

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: The doors are broke.
Noise within
Enter LAERTES, armed; Danes following

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Where is this king? Sirs, stand you all without.

lines.speaker: danes
lines.text: No, let's come in.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: I pray you, give me leave.

lines.speaker: danes
lines.text: We will, we will.
They retire without the door

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: I thank you: keep the door. O thou vile king, Give me my father!

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: Calmly, good Laertes.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: That drop of blood that's calm proclaims me bastard, Cries cuckold to my father, brands the harlot Even here, between the chaste unsmirched brow Of my true mother.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: What is the cause, Laertes, That thy rebellion looks so giant-like? Let him go, Gertrude; do not fear our person: There's such divinity doth hedge a king, That treason can but peep to what it would, Acts little of his will. Tell me, Laertes, Why thou art thus incensed. Let him go, Gertrude. Speak, man.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Where is my father?

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Dead.

lines.speaker: queen gertrude
lines.text: But not by him.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Let him demand his fill.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: How came he dead? I'll not be juggled with: To hell, allegiance! vows, to the blackest devil! Conscience and grace, to the profoundest pit! I dare damnation. To this point I stand, That both the worlds I give to negligence, Let come what comes; only I'll be revenged Most thoroughly for my father.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Who shall stay you?

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: My will, not all the world: And for my means, I'll husband them so well, They shall go far with little.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Good Laertes, If you desire to know the certainty Of your dear father's death, is't writ in your revenge, That, swoopstake, you will draw both friend and foe, Winner and loser?

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: None but his enemies.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Will you know them then?

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: To his good friends thus wide I'll ope my arms; And like the kind life-rendering pelican, Repast them with my blood.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Why, now you speak Like a good child and a true gentleman. That I am guiltless of your father's death, And am most sensible in grief for it, It shall as level to your judgment pierce As day does to your eye.

lines.speaker: danes
lines.text: [Within]                Let her come in.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: How now! what noise is that? O heat, dry up my brains! tears seven times salt, Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye! By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight, Till our scale turn the beam. O rose of May! Dear maid, kind sister, sweet Ophelia! O heavens! is't possible, a young maid's wits Should be as moral as an old man's life? Nature is fine in love, and where 'tis fine, It sends some precious instance of itself After the thing it loves.
Re-enter OPHELIA

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: [Sings] They bore him barefaced on the bier; Hey non nonny, nonny, hey nonny; And in his grave rain'd many a tear:-- Fare you well, my dove!

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade revenge, It could not move thus.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: [Sings] You must sing a-down a-down, An you call him a-down-a. O, how the wheel becomes it! It is the false steward, that stole his master's daughter.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: This nothing's more than matter.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: There's rosemary, that's for remembrance; pray, love, remember: and there is pansies. that's for thoughts.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: A document in madness, thoughts and remembrance fitted.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: There's fennel for you, and columbines: there's rue for you; and here's some for me: we may call it herb-grace o' Sundays: O you must wear your rue with a difference. There's a daisy: I would give you some violets, but they withered all when my father died: they say he made a good end,-- For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy.
Sings

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Thought and affliction, passion, hell itself, She turns to favour and to prettiness.

lines.speaker: ophelia
lines.text: [Sings] And will he not come again? And will he not come again? No, no, he is dead: Go to thy death-bed: He never will come again. His beard was as white as snow, All flaxen was his poll: He is gone, he is gone, And we cast away moan: God ha' mercy on his soul! And of all Christian souls, I pray God. God be wi' ye.
Exit

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Do you see this, O God?

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: Laertes, I must commune with your grief, Or you deny me right. Go but apart, Make choice of whom your wisest friends you will. And they shall hear and judge 'twixt you and me: If by direct or by collateral hand They find us touch'd, we will our kingdom give, Our crown, our life, and all that we can ours, To you in satisfaction; but if not, Be you content to lend your patience to us, And we shall jointly labour with your soul To give it due content.

lines.speaker: laertes
lines.text: Let this be so; His means of death, his obscure funeral-- No trophy, sword, nor hatchment o'er his bones, No noble rite nor formal ostentation-- Cry to be heard, as 'twere from heaven to earth, That I must call't in question.

lines.speaker: king claudius
lines.text: So you shall; And where the offence is let the great axe fall. I pray you, go with me.
Exeunt
